speaker: Neil
text: Hello. This is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I’m Neil.

speaker: body language
text: And I’m Sam. When Neil and I record 6 Minute English face-to-face in the BBC Learning English studio which, I am happy to say, we are doing right now, we look at each other as we speak. We smile and use hand gestures and facial expressions in a type of communication called body language.

speaker: Neil
text: But during the Covid pandemic, everyday meetings with work colleagues, teachers and friends, and 6 Minute English recording - all moved online.

speaker: Sam
text: Video meetings using software like Zoom and Skype became the normal way to communicate with family and friends. And whatever happens with Covid in the future, it seems they’re here to stay.

speaker: Neil
text: In this programme, we’ll be asking: how has body language changed in the world of online video meetings?

speaker: Sam
text: We’ll meet the person who wrote the rulebook for clear communication in the digital age – Erica Dhawan, author of a new book, ‘Digital Body Language’.

speaker: Neil
text: But before that, I have a question for you, Sam, and it’s about Erica Dhawan. She may be a communications expert now, but growing up in Pennsylvania she was a shy and quiet schoolgirl. So how did Erica beat her shyness and become the confident communicator she is today? Did she:

speaker: Neil
text: a) attend public speaking classes?,

speaker: Neil
text: b) copy the body language of the cool kids at school?  or,

speaker: Neil
text: c) raised her hand to answer the teacher’s questions, even if she didn’t know the answer?

speaker: Sam
text: I’ll guess that c – she raised her hand to answer the teacher’s questions.

speaker: Neil
text: OK, Sam. We’ll reveal the correct answer later in the programme.

speaker: eye contact
text: In face-to-face meetings, we immediately see someone’s reaction to what we’ve said through eye contact, where two people look into each other’s eyes as they talk.

speaker: Neil
text: Unfortunately, using a web camera to make eye contact is almost impossible in online meetings and this often creates a kind of ‘distancing’ effect.

speaker: Sam
text: Erica Dhawan makes several suggestions to help with this. See if you can hear the final suggestion she makes to Michael Rosen as part of BBC Radio 4’s Word of Mouth.

speaker: brainstormingprocess
text: And last but not least, slow down. Remember when it was completely normal to have a one-minute pause in a room with one another because we knew when we’re thinking and brainstorming. If we don’t hear someone speak on video, we ask them if they’re on mute. Practise what I call the five-second rule – wait five seconds before speaking to make sure that individuals have time to process the ideas, especially if there may be technology or accessibility issues.

speaker: Sam
text: Did you hear Erica’s last piece of advice, Neil?

speaker: brainstorming
text: Yes, she recommends slowing down, something we do naturally face-to-face when we’re thinking or brainstorming – that’s discussing suggestions with a group of people to come up with new ideas or to solve problems.

speaker: process
text: Slowing down gives us time to process new information – to understand it by thinking carefully and reflecting on it.

speaker: Neil
text: Erica compares online body language to learning a new language - it takes practice, especially when it comes to smiling and laughing, something Michael Rosen finds hard to do in video meetings.

speaker: Sam
text: Listen to him discussing this problem with Erica Dhawan for BBC Radio 4’s, Word of Mouth.

speaker: Michael Rosen
text: Do you think it’s killing off people laughing and smiling in the way we do when we’re altogether in the live situation?

speaker: in unison water cooler effect.
text: I would say that it is much less likely that we laugh and smile on camera for a few reasons. Number one, laughing is often done in unison where we can quickly pick up the energy of someone smiling or laughing and feed off of that and laugh ourselves. When it comes to screen delays, the fact that it’s not natural to see our own camera – being distracted by that – we are much less likely to laugh and smile. One of the ways we can overcome this is by creating intentional moments in our meetings for the water cooler effect.

speaker: in unison
text: Erica points out that laughing often happens in unison – together and at the same time.

speaker: Neil
text: Yes, if someone starts laughing it makes me laugh too.

speaker: Sam
text: She also thinks it’s important to make time for employees to chat informally about things unrelated to work – their weekend plans or last night’s TV show.

speaker: water cooler effect
text: And she uses the expression, the water cooler effect which comes from the United States where office workers sometimes meet at the water fountain to chat.

speaker: water cooler effect
text: So, the water cooler effect refers to informal conversations that people have in their office or workplace, maybe in the lift, the office kitchen or, if there is one, by an actual water cooler.

speaker: Neil
text: Erica Dhawan seems very comfortable communicating online, but she’s had lots of time to practice since her schooldays.

speaker: Sam
text: Ah yes, Neil, in your quiz question you asked how Erica conquered her shyness at school. I guessed that she raised her hand to answer the teacher’s questions.

speaker: Neil
text: It was a good guess, Sam, but the correct answer is b – she copied the body language of her cool teenage classmates, so probably lots of rolled eyes and slouching!

speaker: body language
text: OK, let’s recap the vocabulary from this programme about online body language – non-verbal ways of communicating using the body.

speaker: Eye contact
text: Eye contact is when two people look at each other’s eyes at the same time.

speaker: Brainstorming
text: Brainstorming involves a group discussion to generate new ideas or solutions.

speaker: process
text: When we process information, we think about it carefully in order to understand it.

speaker: In unison
text: In unison means happening together and at the same time

speaker: water cooler effect
text: And finally, the water cooler effect is an American expression to describe informal conversations between people at work.

speaker: Sam
text: Neil is looking at his watch, which is body language that tells me our six minutes are up!

speaker: Neil
text: Goodbye for now!

speaker: Sam
text: Goodbye!
